summary: Living a life marked by violence and racism, neo-Nazi Derek Vinyard (Edward Norton) finally goes to prison after killing two black youths who tried to steal his car. Upon his release, Derek vows to change his ways; he hopes to prevent his younger brother, Danny (Edward Furlong), who idolizes Derek, from following in his footsteps. As he struggles with his own deeply ingrained prejudices and watches their mother grow sicker, Derek wonders if his family can overcome a lifetime of hate.

American History X is a thought-provoking and powerful film that tackles themes of racism, hate, and redemption. Directed by Tony Kaye and starring Edward Norton in a career-defining role, this film is a must-watch for anyone interested in exploring the complex issues of racial tension and violence in America.

The film tells the story of Derek Vinyard, a former neo-Nazi skinhead who is released from prison after serving time for a racially motivated murder. As Derek tries to rebuild his life and repair his relationship with his family, he must confront the hate and bigotry that once consumed him.

The performances in American History X are simply outstanding, with Norton delivering a stunning portrayal of a man struggling to confront the demons of his past. The supporting cast, including Edward Furlong, Beverly D'Angelo, and Stacy Keach, are all excellent as well, bringing a depth and complexity to their characters that makes them feel real and relatable.

But what really sets American History X apart is its unflinching and uncompromising examination of racism and hate. The film doesn't shy away from the ugliness of these issues, but instead confronts them head-on, challenging viewers to examine their own beliefs and prejudices.

The film's cinematography and score are also noteworthy, with the use of black-and-white and color sequences adding to the film's emotional impact, and the haunting score by Anne Dudley perfectly capturing the film's somber tone.

In conclusion, American History X is a must-watch film that tackles important and timely issues in a powerful and thought-provoking way. With its outstanding performances, uncompromising examination of racism and hate, and haunting cinematography and score, it's a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

It is not that I don't think that films should explore this issue as it is important to trace what places these dangerous ideas in the minds of impressionable youths and to show that there is a way to change the views of the most corrosive members of society but sadly this film does not do so adequately.

Derek Vinyard, Edward Norton, became a white supremacist as a result of his father's racist views and eventual death as a result of African-American drug dealers shooting him. He rises up through the ranks quickly in the white supremacist organization Disciples of Christ and influences his impressionable younger brother Danny, Edward Furlong, into adopting his views. He is imprisoned after murdering an African-American and while in prison his prejudices are successfully challenged by African-American inmate Lamont, Guy Torry. He changes his beliefs and is raped by other white supremacists in the prison as a result. When he is released he makes a desperate attempt to convert his younger brother, who is deeply entrenched in the organization, into a non-racist while disassociating himself from his former friends. Danny has been forced to write an essay discussing his brother after provoking his Jewish history teacher Mr. Murray, Elliott Gould, by writing about Mein Kampf. The two bond and after having a serious discussion about race relations Danny is converted and breaks free from the bonds of racism but tragedy befalls him.

The idea that a child would take on the views of their parent is certainly believable as at age ten I took on almost all of the beliefs that my father held, fortunately they were mostly about films. This film did not do enough however to establish Vinyard taking in his father's dangerous ideology as one scene in which his views on "Native Son" are challenged seemed too little to convince. We have previously seen Vinyard's racist rant on television and his angry attack on his teacher at a family lunch but there is more that should be there to support his transition from innocent kid to aggressive racist. There are similar issues in the film's depiction of his loss of his racist views. There is a sort of a "Magical negro" character who is kind to this man who hates him for no reason other than the color of his skin and seems to exist purely to educate him. One particularly laughable scene displays Norton reading a book about African-American history and nodding his head as though in acknowledgement of the fact that the author makes some good points. This is the sort of scene that makes his conversion seem like such a construct and the brevity with which it is seen is disappointing considering the fact that it is what the film turns on.

There are also issues with the way the film in some ways glamorizes white supremacy with a shot of Norton arms outstretched to the sound of gospel music in the background as he is being arrested for murdering a black man truly making him appear like a sympathetic, godlike figure. The wrong person could latch on to this film and see the supremacists as cool and alternative instead of the disgusting, prejudiced people they are. Kaye would have done better not to present Vinyard as a hagiographic figure but to film him during this period of the film as a small, detestable figure who holds no real power and deserves to be looked down upon.

What anchors the film is Norton's impressive performance as he totally commits being utterly terrifying as the horrifying racist and surprisingly convincing as the weak young man susceptible to his father's views. Despite the poor screenplay that cuts corners where it shouldn't have he brings an intensity to the role that is necessary and he does make the story on some level believable.

"American History X" was his very first movie, made in 1998 in Los Angeles, California. Not only did he direct it he also did the cinematography. Main characters Derek Vinyard (Edward Norton) and his younger brother Danny Vinyard (Edward Furlong) not only played great roles but staying in character was their best part. Derek started a neo-nazi skinhead group, violating and discriminating any other race that came in their way, then follows the incarceration of Derek from an incident involving two African American males. The transition following his imprisonment included ironically befriending an African American male. Finally realizing he doesn't want to be a part of that lifestyle any longer, he finds himself trying to save his brother from becoming what he once was. He struggles daily with his past decisions, hoping to bring his family out of it. Creating a satisfying, and heartbreaking film, rating this movie an eight out of ten.

Yes this is a simplistic look on what seems an ageless problem, but that's just it; this movie captures one very narrow angle of a huge and complex problem. This it does extremely well.

American History X is at its best when it's following the protagonist's change in those highly effective prison sequences with his friendship with a black man being the highlight. American History X has one of the most compelling stories I've seen in movies in a while. It's a gut-wrenching, and heartbreaking story. But Tony Kaye's powerful and challenging direction is what made the movie so provocative.

The movie also proves that Edward Norton has a huge talent that, unfortunately, has been wasted. Norton delivered the performance of his career in this movie. A performance that elevated the entire movie. While Derek Vinyard, Norton's character, has the most powerful lines in the movie, they wouldn't have been as powerful as they are without Edward Norton's staggering delivering.

Also, Edward Norton's performance may be the only thing that remained sharp and solid throughout the whole movie. Because aside from Norton's riveting and smart monologues, the dialogue in this movie, especially at the first two acts, is so weak and often cheesy! The things got better at the last act but at that time I was wondering why the dialogue wasn't that good most of the movie. It's really baffling because the movie needed badly to have a decent and strong dialogue from its beginning, considering its subject matter. The dialogue often was too on the nose and preachy while it should have served its already gripping story. That also made some scenes in the movie feel so awkward and heavy-handed.

The dialogue isn't the only, or the biggest issue I've with American History X. As I think that everything related to the Neo Nazi gang is completely underdeveloped. Which is a shame because they play a pivotal part in the story. They are part of the main plot, so to speak.

Besides that balancing between two contradictory aspects of the story, Tony Kaye with his mixture of black & white history contrasting with colorful reality is magic to absorb and shows this film up to be what it is. Smoothly moving camera in the scenes in Black and White that are set in the past to convey an unsettling feeling, and bleak and restrained colored scenes to match the dystopian-like present.

American History X had to walk a fine line. It’s telling a story where it would be easy to make despicable people appear sympathetic. It focuses in on a neo-Nazi and tells how the events in his life filled him with hate, and how his hate has affected his family and friends. The big relationship in the film is between this man and his younger brother who idolizes him and wants to follow in his footsteps. I thought they did an admirable job of making it clear that the ideals these boys were fighting for are awful, but they themselves are not pure evil and might have some good in them. I didn’t like how they setup this plot point, though. The weird writing assignment that started the whole story was kind of odd and felt forced. I just didn’t think it fit with the structure of the film. Edward Norton was superb as he always tends to be when he commits to a role. There are at least 3 or 4 different stages in the journey of this character that he has to portray and I think he nails them all. From the beginning when he’s pure rage, to the flashbacks where he’s somewhat innocent, and then the later scenes where he’s repentant, you can track that journey without it being an open topic of discussion. He makes it all clear through his behavior. Edward Furlong is also amazing as the younger brother. He hits that perfect balance of presenting himself as an adult who has his mind made up and is in control of everything, but also betraying an underlying innocence that shows he’s only following others down a path and hasn’t truly decided for himself. The artistic choice of using black-and-white for flashbacks and color for the present day scenes worked for me also. It spoke to the changing mindset of Norton’s character, and also made those flashbacks feel grittier. I found this movie engaging and authentic, but also hard to watch. It goes on the list of films that I respect, but I can’t imagine sitting through it again. It’s not that the story is structured poorly or that it was boring, nothing that would typically keep me away from re-watching a movie. In this case it’s just the fact that many of the events are depressing and the ideals we see espoused are hard to swallow. American History X is a solid film, and I think the point it makes is one we all need to hear. But I’ve heard it once now, and I don’t need to go through that again.

In 2016, I repeatedly watched legions of Americans, mostly whites, embrace and/or ignore Donald Trump's inflammatory rhetoric that dehumanized everyone who was not a white heterosexual man, and we rewarded him with the title of President of the United States. This tragedy reinforces the idea that Americans, and frankly humans, continue to fear what they do not understand, therefore cultivating unnecessarily harmful tension that frequently leads to conflict. This conflict makes us no different than our primitive descendants, and it undermines our potential to make the world a better place. I firmly believe American History X is a beacon of hope America needs to eventually overcome its racial divide, despite a President who will always fly the "woe is the white race" flag. 

The film's backbone is unquestionably Edward Norton's performance as Derek Vinyard, a despicable and morally repugnant neo-Nazi who undergoes a believably human transformation. His unflinching and versatile performance gives credence to every line of dialogue and every action in every scene, which elevates all the performances in the film's supporting cast. As a result, I bought Vinyard's history and every interaction he has with his family, particularly his relationship with his younger brother.  I firmly believe Norton's performance is so outstanding that it is among  the five greatest performances of all-time. 

However, Norton's performance would not have been nearly as impactful if Tony Kaye's storytelling felt like a structured narrative. Though it is not nearly as experiential as Moonlight, I became emotionally attached to the characters because I concurrently bought them as people and the complicated world they all inhabited. Whomever accuses the film of being preachy or heavy-handed is simply not recognizing that its message organically arises vicariously through its characters during their transformations, particularly the Vinyard brothers. Last, but not least, I absolutely love that there is a particular line of dialogue that suggest Derek has not gone completely to the other side of the moral spectrum, which highlights the time and understanding it takes to ultimately get there. 

Last, but not least, I love that Tony Kaye chose to tint the flashback sequences black-and-white and the present sequences in color. The gimmick works tremendously because not only does it clearly illustrate what happens in the past and present, but it also illustrates how all the characters look at racism in those moments in time. Contrary to popular belief, race is unquestionably the most complicated issue that has plagued human history, yet we, especially Americans, continually try to categorically break it down into good and bad and/or right and wrong.  

As much as I love this film, I have a few quibbles with it. First, there are a couple scenes that have unnecessary exposition, both dialogue and voiceover. Second, there are a few times when Kaye uses a medium close-up instead of a regular close-up to show a character's reaction, though I understand why he chose to do so. Last, there is one scene where the rhetoric could have been toned down to dramatically play up the rhetoric's impact on a certain character.   

Overall, this is an emotionally riveting film that tactfully dissects race and explores how hatred undermines and eventually destroys understanding on an interpersonal, a familial and a societal level. Most importantly, it demonstrates how anyone, no matter how racially insensitive, can redeem themselves from those harmful beliefs by simply exposing themselves to different people in different cultures in an open-minded effort to understand those people and their cultural backgrounds. 

This film reminded me to not give up on Donald Trump and his ardent supporters because if we give up on them, then they will have no desire to change, which will only make the world a harsher and more violent place to live.

Hate isn't something we're born with, unless you're Damien from "The Omen" or are fresh out of Rosemary's womb.  It is a feature of one's personality distinctly inspired by others - the kids of the Westboro Baptist Church didn't come into the world with the understanding that the right thing to do is to be homophobic and anti-Semitic.  They were taught these diseases.  Most of the population is able to cope by ignoring them, living bigot-free lives in the meantime - but knowing that groups believing that another race, religion, sexuality, etc., is so wrong that they would not oppose violence to oppress it is a terrifying, unsettling thing. 
	"American History X" shines a light on to the scarring truths of neo-Nazism in the United States, informing us that groups committed to their hate, committed to viewing Adolf Hitler as a sort of misunderstood Jesus, is a very real, very scary reality.  Rationalism plays no part in their antics; it is rage that they disguise as social justice.  The film is frightening, upsetting, and visceral.  It is more relevant than ever, with Donald Trump's candidacy bringing out tucked away racism embedded in the worst individuals of the U.S.  
	Surprisingly, "American History X" is still, nevertheless, moving.  While it gives us a taste of the brutalities of neo-Nazism, it doesn't waste away potential by basking in a senselessly angry rhetoric.  There's a twist: what if one of the biggest doers of violence against minorities went to jail, realized his evils, and was reborn? The answer isn't as easy as we would like it to be.  But it's a captivating one.
	The film opens with a distressful sequence that details a carjacking gone wrong - would-be thieves make the mistake of targeting the home of Derek Vinyard (Edward Norton), a merciless neo-Nazi.  Being mostly black, they are murdered in methods ranging from vicious to grotesque.  Derek is sent to prison for three years, his younger brother, the impressionable, teenaged Danny (Edward Furlong), imitating his hateful tactics as he ages.
	The present of the film is set during the window of the first few weeks of Derek's release.  Danny has just written a paper praising Mein Kampf, and the skinhead movement is growing.  But something in Derek has changed.  Gone is the evil that nested in his eyes before; his body language suggests someone no longer compelled to always be in attack mode.  
	Flashbacks, photographed in grimy black-and-white, reveal his metamorphosis, and we unromantically witness everything from Derek's sordid days as a sadistic "leader" to his eye-opening incarnation, where he forms such a strong bond with a fellow inmate (who happens to be black) that it causes him to rethink his hateful ways.
	So the film is intent on acting as voyeur to Derek's desperate attempts to inspire Danny to reconsider his life, reconsider his beliefs and wonder aloud if over-the-top prejudice is a path worth traveling down.  "American History X" doesn't paint Derek as a saint (we very graphically see the atrocities of his past), making the film gripping because it analyzes what a shallow thing hate is in a thoughtful, nuanced way.
	Tony Kaye's direction, unflinching and unbiased, presents the situation as is, letting the emotional undertones of the film hit us naturally, and, in some ways, guttingly.  His instincts complement David McKenna's brilliant screenplay with fluidity; McKenna, so easily able to go back and forth tonally (authentically characterizing a skinhead crime spree only to suddenly transition into Derek's regretful present), gives the film its magnetically flawed interior.  Kaye provides it with its instinctual exterior.  We are never less than transfixed.  It is even entertaining, despite its frequent dives into jerking uncomfortability.
	The ensemble is just as monumentally stunning, if not more so.  Norton gives the performance of his career, embodying Derek with such commitment that to go from despising him to sympathizing with him does not feel like a cinematic manipulation; his portrayal is multifaceted in ways few actors can imitate.  We can feel his pain, his sorrow, his regret.  Though I wish more time was spent following Derek's descent from all-American teenagerisms to neo-Nazi masochism, it doesn't corrupt the power of Norton's characterization.
	Furlong is heartbreaking as Derek's vulnerable younger brother who will do anything to be accepted; in a climactic dinner scene that shows the moment during which their father passes his bigoted baton to Derek, Furlong is only a background figure.  But look at the way his eyes change, the way they see that hate equals acceptance, love.  Furlong's subtle facial idiosyncrasies and unconfident body language gives Danny a dimension that suggests that his hate is a result of social pressure, not of genuine disdain.
	Even the supporting players, whose good work could be overlooked when behind the ground-shattering performances of Norton and Furlong, enrapture us.  Beverly D'Angelo, the film's source of hope, is heartfelt as a mother disgusted by the sins of her sons that still manages to radiate with unwavering love; conversely, Fairuza Balk, as Derek's pre-prison girlfriend, disturbs with her inability to see past the fury that clouds her judgment.
	Society will continue to contain pockets of narrow-minded individuals reactionary and caustic, but "American History X" uncovers the reality that racism and its fellow prejudices are something unfortunately characterized by the culture that surrounds them - hate, in truth, has no foundation besides a bottomless crevasse where misanthropy immortally lives.  The only way out is to open one's eyes; "American History X" is unmistakably hopeful and unmistakably timeless.

American History X, the film that everyone apparently thinks is one of the most important films of all time, falls into yet another slot on the ever-growing list of movies that I disagree with seemingly everyone on. No, this is not an intrinsically good film. I don't believe that a movie should be awarded points simply because it tackles tough subjects, and I don't think that the subject itself should have any serious weight in the overall opinion of it. If you're a religious person and you watch The Passion of the Christ, you can't say it's a good movie purely based on the fact that it's about something you believe in. The key to good filmmaking is the way the directors, actors, and writers go about portraying the subjects at hand; regardless of who or what the subjects are. And although race relations in America are tense at best, and deserve close examination, that alone does not constitute a good movie.

American History X is the story of a neo-nazi (Edward Norton) who, after a brief 3-year stint in a prison, becomes reformed and tries to turn his little brother on another path than his own. Okay, already I see problems here. Norton's character went to jail because he killed two black guys in the street. Yes, they were bashing up his truck. However, do we really believe that a known white supremacist could wound a guy, curb-stomp him to death, and then get only three years in jail? I mean, maybe in Florida, but not LA. I'm getting sidetracked. The point is, there are key elements of the plot that make no sense, especially what causes Norton to change (spoilers ahead). After seeing the drastic before and after comparisons between pre-jail and post-jail Norton, the audience is waiting for the one defining and incredible event that turned this hateful person around and onto the path of redemption.

Yeah, long story short, that never happens. Norton's story in jail is extremely disappointing. Firstly, he starts to fall out of favor with his fellow white supremacists when they do drug deals with the Mexicans in the prison. Okay... so he got mad at the white guys for doing business with the brown guys, so now he'll side with the brown guys? No, that doesn't make sense. Then the white supremacists rape him in the showers. So that one experience forever altered his world view and made him a kinder, more accepting, gentler human being? Ridiculous! And the last contributing factor is the fact that he makes friends with a black guy on the inside, leading to the black guys not killing him. Wow, there's so much wrong with this premise. I didn't believe for a second that this hateful, ignorant, and self-righteous piece of shit could go through such an incredible transformation in the span of three years. Spare me that "people change" bullshit-- the fact of the matter is that this could never have happened, EVER.

The one consistent high point is Norton, who is extremely convincing during the flashbacks to his hateful, bigoted past. There's a dinner table scene that is especially well-scripted and acted, where Norton bares a swastika on his chest to a Jewish dinner guest. Eep. Just gonna go out on a limb and say that those are bad table manners. In all seriousness though, it's difficult to play a character that is this reprehensible (Michael Fassbender knows it), but Norton pulls it off. The problem here is that we are then expected to feel sympathy for this character. Well, forgive me if I'm not so quick to forget the fact that this guy was a white supremacist three years ago. Then there's the dialogue between him and his little brother, which is so bad it sounds like it was ad-libbed right on the spot. It's repetitive, corny, forced, and wholly uninteresting. These are great characters, but they seriously deserved a better movie.

Final Score for American History X: 4/10 stars. I really wanted to like this film, but unfortunately it ultimately collapses under the weight of the subjects it's covering without actually providing any real substance. The story is questionable at best, the dialogue is laughable for the most part, and the acting, although good, isn't strong enough to hold up the entire movie. Adding to that is the Requiem For A Dream-style way that this film tells us something we already know: Here, instead of "drugs are bad," it's "racism is bad." It tries to have a new take on the subject by trying to make its main character sympathetic... but if the best you can do is try to make me become emotionally attached to a nazi, then I'll gladly take genericness instead.

American History X is the greatest film since Romper Stomper to deal directly with the neo-Nazi movement, and in a similar manner it does it in the most powerful way: through depicting the savage brutality of the movement.
American History X is one of the most savagely brutal crime dramas to ever be so small scaled and devoted to its characters while understanding the wider world beyond him, as in how his beliefs and actions prove to impact on the people around him. And through a strong screenplay, intense direction, amazing acting and powerful visuals, American History X succeeds in every area.
Like I said, American History X gets its brutal story dynamics up close and personal with the viewers by shocking them with it. And its all shot perfectly and stylishly so that the hauntingly intense atmosphere manages to thrill viewers with its feel and its look. All the dramatics are shot well with fine cinematography and edited perfectly, even getting a little more intense thanks to the touch of the musical score.
The musical score in American History X is immensely beautiful and helps the emotional drama of the story move along as it explores all the complicated territory that David McKenna writes into it.
Really, American History X is a very complicated film which has a story that touches on dark territory but never crosses the line no matter how hard it pushes. And the screenplay treats the characters well because its so brutally honest with how they speak and think that the product is almost unbearable for viewers. But those who can bear and appreciate it will be amazed by the true quality of American History X. I know I was.
American History X is an unforgettable film as an intense visual experience and an emotional one, and thanks to the direction of Tony Kaye, it never falls short of its potential or downgrades its utter brutality.
But the standout quality is the acting which isn't just amazing, its immaculate.
Edward Norton's performance is savagely unforgettable. After playing the simultaneously villainous and fragile Aaron Stampler in Primal Fear, he steps up into the almost impossibly intimidating role of violent and sadistic neo-Nazi Derek Vinyard in American History X and gives a performance so powerful and so intimidating that I would be lying if I said it didn't leave me physically shaking. The utter brutality Edward Norton puts into characterising Derek Vinyard's absolute hate for Asians, Blacks and Jews is incredibly poweruful and combined with his muscular stature and the stare in his eyes that pierce the screen as if they see straight into hell makes it the greatest performance of his career. Its easy to play a person that turns into a villain, but its much more difficult to play someone going the other way, particularly one that is covered in violent muscles and neo-Nazi tattoo's. And yet Edward Norton proves how to do it. While the film itself does assist the development by having an emotional atmosphere which is constantly changing, all the responsibility rests on Edward Norton's shoulders as he carries the story through all of its dramatic territory with an immensely powerful and unflinching dramatic lead role. Edward Norton truly is an incredible actor, and his name should be more popular today than many others. Even though he lost the Academy Award for Best Actor to Roberto Benigni for La Vita E Bella (Life is Beautiful) who gave what I deem to be the single greatest performance in cinematic history, he still gave an unforgettable performance packed to the brim with talent that cannot be taught and only comes from deep within the heart of a truly passionate actor.

And teamed up with him is the talented young Edward Furlong, the actor famous for his dead-on performance as John Connor in Terminator 2: Judgement Day, the film has a real connection of brotherly chemistry to it to enhance its quality and give it a more powerful impact. And thanks to the efforts of Edward Furlong its successful in that area because he has a powerful confidence to him as an actor which he instils into the role of Danny Vinyard and gives the story a good supporting character to assist in characterising the main character Derek Vinyard. He constantly is a figure of interest and the performance of Edward Furlong is dead on in capturing the emotional drama of the role. His line delivery is fierce and the stare in his eye is damaging, but what is perfect is his physicality which enhances the idea that he is the brother of Derek Vinyard by giving him a sense of intimidation. His gritty physical shell and dramatic depth make him a great cast member in American History X and makes me wonder where his career has gone.
Beverly D'Angelo gives the strongest dramatic performance of her career in American History X. While she's memorable for her comedic work in the National Lampoon's Vacation series of films, she makes more of an impact for her role in American History X. She shows what makes her a great actress. Its her talent for building a dramatic atmosphere in what she is saying gradually until in one big burst she lets it all out in an explosion of climactic drama. It's incredibly impressive that she, the woman who portrayed Ellen Griswold, is actually the woman playing the mother of a sadistic neo-Nazi and doing it so well with such a passion for the drama in the story. She really is a great actress in American History X, and up until now I've only seen her as a good actress.
Guy Torry also manages to do a good job due to his consistency as an actor with strong line delivery.

So American History X is a brutal and overpoweringly incredible drama film which displays the greatest talents of actors Edward Norton and Beverly D'Angelo as well as handling its tricky and dark subject matter so well.

After the death of their father, brothers Derek (Edward Norton) and Danny (Edward Furlong) fall under the sway of a radical white supremacist. Derek becomes an obscenity-spewing leader of a white gang that trashes immigrant-run corner stores and chases black neighbours out of local parks. He eventually goes too far and ends up in prison for a vicious, brutal murder. While he is out of sight, his legend grows among the skinhead crowd and younger brother Danny goes along with the vitriol (although there are some indications that Danny doesn't totally buy into the Aryan ideology). Finally, Derek is released a changed man and does his best to save Danny from the cycle of hate and violence.

The movie is told through a combination of present-day scenes after Derek's release and flashbacks (filmed in crystal-clear black and white) of the murder and Derek's time in prison, where we see how he comes to recognize the white supremacists' preaching to be utterly false.

This is a difficult and disturbing film to watch. I watched it with a high-school teacher whose students repeatedly tell her how awesome it is. Clearly, some teenagers are completely missing the point, which is always a danger when presenting such hate-filled behaviour in a realistic way. The weak-minded will see it as glorifying a point of view that in fact it is showing as utterly abhorrent.

This film presents a view of a life that middle-class viewers like me have never experienced and I hope never will. I know these attitudes and actions exist, but I don't really know what purpose is served by putting them on the screen.

It definitely has its flaws, but they're comprehensively outweighed by its strengths. As for being "simplistic" and "preachy", I can't agree. The former is true only in as much as its necessary when telling a story like this in a movie rather than a book; the latter I can't see at all - I really appreciated characters not being clumsy stereotypes of either good or bad and, for that matter, that black and white are complex, believable people spread across the spectrum of decency regardless of colour.

American History X is about the idea that prejudice and bigotry will kill our children. The idea is that prejudice is a slippery slope. A father's offhanded racist remark over the dinner can lead to unintended consequences. The result, in the world of this movie, is children killing each other. The movie makes a pretty convincing argument that the consequences in our world would be just as dire, that there is no room for even a little bit of bigotry in our society if we are to survive without killing each other.

American History X goes about proving this idea with two main plots: the internal plot of Derek's redemption from being a skinhead Nazi to a tolerant individual actively helping the good cause and the external plot of Derek's attempt to save his younger brother Danny from the brainwashing that ruined him. Derek is successful in redeeming himself, but his attempt to save Danny fails when Danny is shot and killed. This suggests that even if we live with hate in a momentary weakness, that hate will have consequences far beyond the moment. The movie suggests that with hate, there is no such thing as true redemption. Therefore, we are all well-advised to avoid even a little bit of it.

The movie makes the idea fully believable because of the depths of hate and true redemption Derek goes through. He seemed to have finally won the battle to save both his family's soul when his past all of a sudden catches up to him and kills Danny. This twist at the end makes it impossible to finish the movie feeling good about ourselves that the hero has won his redemption through his trials by fire. It makes it impossible not to think and feel and believe that hate will eventually catch up to all of us if we let it in for even a little bit. Great idea and a great movie.

Tony Kaye delivers a masterful directorial debut with his film American History X which delves into dark territory. American History X, for me, was quite difficult to watch. In a world where race equality was always stressed in my surroundings, it truly hit me like a ton of bricks seeing the white supremacist Neo-Nazi movements in American History X. It takes a lot to get to me when it comes to dramatic films, and Kaye had me from the moment the opening credits rolled. The use of black and white cinematography to differentiate between past and present experiences was truly something unexpected for a film about Neo-Nazi movements. Nevertheless, Kaye's motif of black and white filming style showed how the world that he was showing was nothing short of black and white in the eyes of Derek Vinyard. Flashing to the present moments of the movie, after Derek was released from his three-year sentence in federal prison for voluntary manslaughter, we see the colored cinematography seeing that black and white have blended together as one and that a world of color has opened to Derek's eyes just through a simple change of color. A subtle, but brilliant direction choice from a novice director is something that is nice to see! Now, I must mention the sensational Academy Award nominated performance of the spine-chilling Edward Norton (Primal Fear, The Illusionist, Fight Club). Norton's raw performance is the natural highlight of the movie. The clash Norton shows between the reformed and the flawed Derek Vinyard just through his actions is nothing short of a masterful actor in his key environment. Be this as it may, I cannot overshadow the supporting performances of Edward Furlong and Beverley D'Angelo. Furlong's performance of Danny Vinyard shows the necessity to impress a brother through actions not words. Though this ultimately can be construed as Danny's tragic flaw, we see Furlong ace this part in spades. D'Angelo's raw performance as a flawed, ill mother attempting to break through to her two sons breaks your heart during a confrontational scene between Derek and his mother at Derek's prison. Exploring motifs of race, gangs, race riots, prison, rape, antisemitism, and Neo-Nazi movements, American History X delves into uncharted territory for a film from the late 1990's, and shines as an ideal history lesson to the negative sections that darken  American History.

When films dare to tackle racism it can fall into a trap of just being offensive itself. How much racism and discrimination can one put into a movie before its message becomes lost? American History X is about a former neo-nazi skinhead trying to prevent his younger brother from going down the same wrong path that he did. The main character are white supremacists which limits the audiences in terms in how much we can relate to them. What is universally relatable is the protagonist idea of hate. While not on the same level as the protagonists we all have been hated or hated someone whether for petty or good reasoning behind it. The most powerful element of the plot is its protagonist. Seeing his transformation and development into a different person is powerfully symbolic. It feels natural, realistic, and even inspiring to have an entirely new perspective on race and life.

A major complaint on the plot is the younger brother not being as developed. All we know is that he took influence from his older brother behavior and is having trouble at school. He felt secondary despite narrating the story and being a huge focused in the beginning of the film. As for the ending of the film it is shocking not for the right reason. It got acrossed its anti racist message boldly, but at the cost of any emotional resonate with that character.

Also in the film whenever a problem occurred when black people were present they would start trouble. The opening scene, a dispute in a basketball game, the scene where Danny Vinyard confronts Little Henry in the restroom, and the ending. It's seemed more than just coincidence, but given the nature of the characters one can't really call it discriminative. It is a major part of Norton and Furlong characters to be racist and these encounters better help illustrate the transformations. Not a major flaw, but one odd observation when viewing that difficult to look past.  

Of course no review of this film would be complete without mentioning Edward Norton. He's simply at top form here. He is very well believable as a Neo-Nazi as well as the reformed person. It's almost like he's playing 2 different characters and he does that so extremely well. It not just balancing the range of his character, but the dimension of his life. Changing himself psychologically, socially, and politically in natural form to make the root of the film works. It is Edward Norton film and it's because his performance that the film works as great as it does.

American History X perfectly balances walking a thin line of tackling racism true to nature without ever becoming just a film piece to simply be offensive. It themes are universal, the performance by Edward Norton is easily his best, and overall a great movie with a positive to boost.

It's basically a tale of how this one youth, Derek, affected by the death of his father who died in the hands of a Negro, turns into a Skinhead and becomes extremely racist. Soon his brother, Danny wishes to follow in his brother's footsteps just when Derek is sent to jail. It is from then on that Derek wishes for his brother to turn away from it all. On the technical side, Anne Dudley has also provided a wonderful score for this movie as well. Honestly, I was half-expecting mostly heavy metal, punk, hard rock sort of soundtrack, something which I would usually hear from most skinhead movies, but instead, I got well-written orchestral music bursting from the speakers as the images played by. The cinematography is okay, using black & white mode to depict events from the past and colours for those in the present time. The screenplay is also well-done, inserting small bits of simple everyday humour effectively into the dialogues. The plot may have been quite predictable, but the film makes one fall in love with the characters so much (especially Edward Furlong's and Edward Norton's characters) so much so that, even if one were to have foreseen what was coming in the end, one would still feel emotionally affected by it. Given the way the story unfolds I would have expected this to be based on a book and the way the film opens effectively sets the mood really well and the film is gritty and real. I like the use of Black and White for the flashbacks and colour for the present day, even if I originally thought the film would be all in Black and White given that the only promotional images of the film I saw were in Black and White.
